text: Yo if anyone wants to chat DM me   In scientific taxonomy  toads are found in the families Bufonidae  Bombinatoridae  Calyptocephalellidae  Discoglossidae  Myobatrachidae  Pelobatidae  Rhinophrynidae  Scaphiopodidae and Microhylidae Usually the largest of the bumps on the skin of a toad are those that cover the parotoid glands  The bumps are commonly called warts  but they have nothing to do with pathologic warts  being fixed in size  present on healthy specimens and not caused by infection unreliable source  Toads travel from non breeding to breeding areas of ponds and lakes  Bogert   suggests that the toads  call is the most important cue in the homing to ponds  Toads  like many amphibians  exhibit breeding site fidelity  philopatry  Individual American toads return to their natal ponds to breed where they are likely to encounter siblings as potential mates  Although inbred examples within a species is possible  siblings rarely mate  Toads recognize and avoid mating with close kin  Advertisement vocalizations given by males appear to serve as cues by which females recognize kin  Kin recognition thus allows avoidance of inbreeding and consequent inbreeding depression
summary: Toads are found in the families Bufonidae, Bombinatoridae, Calyptocephalellidae, Discoglossidae, Pelobatrachidae, Rhinophrynidae, Scaphiopodidae and Microhylidae. Bogert suggests that the toads call is the most important cue in the homing to ponds. American toads return to their natal ponds to breed.
